messageBody:
On Sat, 5 May 2001, [iso-8859-1] Michael LÃ©pine wrote:

> I am fairly new to JUnit and am leading its integration at work. The one
> question I get a lot is, "How do we test the results of a database query?"
> The former method of testing the query, was to manually review the results.
> The one solution we've come up with is to perform the query, save the
> results to a file, then assert that the results from the live query are
> equivalent to the stored results in the file. This gets a little more tricky
> when the results data contains time-sensitive fields (i.e. date fields).
>
> Anyway, I just wanted to know whether anyone had come up with a simpler
> and/or better solution.

What I do for this sort of thing (not databases, mind you) is to
use the output from toString() as the test. If that isn't suitable,
I'll make a method that suits the test better. This method can
replace things like time-sensitive fields with fixed values so that
tests don't break.

My tests send up being simple assertEquals against two strings,
one coming from a static constant, the other from the result object.

I wrote a little tool in perl that reads an input file and writes a
java statement that reproduces the file as a string. I've used this
to take captured results and convert them to reference data for use in
Unit tests.
